posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18899481
Similar experience here. I tried the much-touted Subway roast beef sub. Supposedly, according to social media posts that were "totally genuine and not paid-for marketing", it was a good fast food item enjoyed by many.
I ordered the sandwich and received what appeared to be a disheveled wad of paper, perhaps something to toss in the refuse bin. However, I was assured that my supposedly tasty treat was inside.
I followed the instructions and, upon removing the many layers of questionable wrapping material, was met with what appeared to be a "food-related item" that suffered a tumble down a set of stairs before being stomped under a steel toe boot.
Now, I'm not one to decry fast food presentation differing from advertisements, they all do it. But this seemed to be crossing the line. Nevertheless, I knew that presentation wasn't everything, so I carried on. I picked up the scrambled mass and, upon bringing it to my mouth, was hit with a pungent aroma that seemed to seat itself in the back of my sinus. Tears welled in my eyes as I opened my mouth and took my first (and only) bite. I tasted nothing upon entry. I tasted nothing upon the first bite of the chew. I chewed thrice more before "flavor" made itself known. It was not a welcome one. I have never had the displeasure of chewing on an old dishrag that had been dropped and forgotten behind a restaurant dishwasher, but this must have been its closest "edible" imitation.
I let the chewed mass fall from my mouth, back into the so-called "wrapper", letting it dribble upon the supposed "sandwich". I went to the nearest drug store and bought mouth wash - it took 5 cycles to rinse out the taste. Unfortunately, the pungent aroma that had seated itself in my sinus would persist for hours.

It was not until I stopped at my local Arby's restaurant and ordered a Roast Beef Sandwich that I had would have a sandwich worthy of the day. And a much-enjoyed one, at that. I highly recommend everyone try Arby's Roast Beef.

Get a gravity one. Get a good brand like Berkel, small diameter blade (size of the blade decides a lot of the cost and it's irrelevant at home). Look at second hand/auction sites and be quick, professional butchers are hawking them 24/7 for good reason, these things last decades.

Don't buy cheap garbage though. Your meats will come out shrivelled, your onions soggy, your cheeses mushy and torn. They're hell to clean and a recipe for accidents.

>>18900636
>Could I still gong fu brew it with a gawain like
A cheap porcelain gaiwan is all you really need. Yixing maybe makes a slight difference but it is not work worrying about when starting out.

>If i keep the boxes I have closed and outside of light they should last a long time right?
Those teas should be fine indefinitely if they came sealed up well. You could stick the boxes in a ziplock bags for additional protection if you want. How did the tea come stored in the boxes?

>>18900733
>Is an electric kettle with a temperature setting where it can keep the water at a certain temp necessary?
For puerh boiling or just off boiling water is what is typically used. An electric kettle that you can set to lower temperatures is nice for green tea and being able to keep the water hot is convenient but you don't need one starting out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I usually make fried rice with chicken, chinese bbq pork, egg, onion, peas and carrots. Marinate chicken with a little soy sauce and shaoxing wine then fry it up and set aside. Then fry onion until it's given up most of the moisture and add a little garlic and set aside. Next fry the rice (I like peanut oil best for this dish) and add all the ingredients back plus some salt pepper and a little more soy sauce. I use high heat for the chicken to get some color on it then turn it down to medium high for the rest.

>>18905894
Most important thing with fried rice is you wanna have all your ingredients ready to go, everything chopped and prepped ahead of time cuz the best fried rice is cooked fast. This includes the protein. I usually cook the egg and meat right before but Ieftover stuff is fine too.

I use a wok on a shitty electric coil stove on high heat, season with peanut oil, start with shallot or onion, carrot, garlic (sometimes ginger) until the carrots are tender. I add in the meat component at this point to warm it up (spam most often, but I've also done rotisserie chicken or strips of beef) then the rice goes in. I try and spread the rice around with as much direct contact with the wok as possible, leave it for a min or so to get crispy, then start tossing the rice on very high heat. After a few minutes of tossing, I make a well and add sambal chili sauce and fry it a bit. Add scallion whites and toss. At this point I taste it, add MSG, salt, pepper, soy sauce, oyster sauce, sesame oil and toss. Taste again and adjust seasoning, toss, serve with chopped green onion and sesame seeds.

There's no worthwhile point in using a wok on electric elements.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18908544
Put your empty pan on high heat and let it get hot. Add in some canola/vegetable/peanut oil, anything with a high smoke point and let it coat the entire surface of the pan. Bring up the temp and when the oil starts to smoke, remove than pan from the heat and let it cool down a bit. Use a paper towel to remove any excess oil and you're ready to go. You just got a thin layer of oil to polymerize itself onto the steel and it will now act as a non stick barrier. If you did it right you will be able to crack an egg into your stainless pan with no additional oil and it will slide around on the cooking surface with no effort.

>>18908575
There is no stuck egg friend, that little bit of brown on the pan is rice not getting moved quick enough. It still came off the pan with hot water so it wasn't really stuck on.

>>18908579
If you need bartenders friend to do day to day cleaning on your stainless, you're doing something wrong. That product is only needed to remove the build up of oil that has been drastically overheated (if you want to). I honestly haven't had to use it in over a year.

>>18903665
>Non-American here. Does kosher salt taste any different to.... not kosher salt?
It's miss labeled. Salt isn't kosher or not, it's just salt. What is called kosher salt should more correctly be called koshering salt and was/is used to cure meats into a kosher food.

All the kosher part indicates is that it's suitable for curing a meat because of the size of the chunks. Any recipe that uses kosher salt but otherwise dissolves it is just pretending to be fancy by using a slightly more expensive salt. (no salt is really expensive in the modern world).

I tend to aire on the spicy side when it comes to ramen. What I used to do when I worked down the road from the Korean store:
>go into store with $20
>buy $20 worth of individual packs of ramen I had not tried before
>try all of them
>decide what I liked from that bunch and took pictures of the package (because lol some of them don't have any engrish text)
>return to store the next time
>repeat process
Some recommendations:
>paldo namja (kicks the shit out of Shin Black imo)
>paldo teumsae
>paldo jjajangmen
>any samyang buldak varieties
>I prefer the cheese kind
>did not like the carbonara or curry
>ottogi sesame with the egg block
>regular shin is fine if you're planning on adding stuff to it or experimenting with the "ramen hacks" that pop up all the time
>I recommend avoiding buying too many cold noodle varieties unless you've verified that you like them already

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18878544
>Any recommendations from /ck/?
make your own
a bulk pack of dried ramen and a can of vegeta only takes 5 minutes + however long it takes to get the water boiling (and costs far less per serve than packets of instant), and you can improve it from there by making stock yourself, using fresh meat or vegetables, a splash of soy sauce or hoisin or some other sauce, aroma oils etc.
It's also less wasteful since you aren't throwing away massive amounts of plastic wrapping, foil sauce packets.
Once you start making your own you'll quickly realise how oily and artificial the instant ramens are.

I don't think I can summarise geopolitics and international business into a 4channel post, but I'll try
Basically they have different costs for inputs to make the ramen and they have separate diplomatic relations with the US results in different trade agreements. Japan has always had an isolationist mentality making many of their items less in supply and more in demand, raising their price. Japan is a small island. China is much larger and connected to greater Asia, Russia, India. They mass produce everything resulting in higher supply, lower demand and therefore lower price

>>18888686
Somalis eat a banana with literally every dish. It's weird, but primitive countries generally don't have a rigid distinction between sweet and savoury dishes the way they do. In some regions of Uganda, boiled bananas are their staple carb, they eat dishes such as boiled bananas with beans.

Another weird thing done with spaghetti in Africa is the Ethiopian way of eating it. They eat spaghetti in tomato sauce but the whole thing is served on an injera (very thin pancake made of teff wheat, with a sour taste because the dough is left to ferment for a few days). See pic related for an example.

>adding tomato to ceviche makes it mexican
The Mexican ceviche is not simply a tomato on top of the "original" recipe though. Not only is the tomato incorporated into the dish, other ingredients are also substituted from the south American variant due to differing availability. For example, in Peru (claims to have invented it), they also add hot peppers that Mexicans did not traditionally have access to.
>adding cream to carbonara makes it british/american
It's still Italian with cream. Yes, Italians did make it with cream themselves (albeit less commonly) despite what LARPing purists would have you believe, there are published Italian recipe books that instruct adding cream.

posts.com:
>>18902536
I make a lot of deviled eggs
Like, the egg prices are hurting me
There are only two things that ensure you can peel the egg easily
That you steam them, and you shock them in ice water immediately
When you steam an egg you might want to poke a hole in the air pocket with a safety needle or thumbtack
Rotate the needle, don't push it straight in
Everything else is luck of the draw
I've tried old eggs, dried eggs, warm eggs, cold eggs, none of those matter

One thing to make sure they come out pretty and uniform is to get grade AA
They will also center better if you cook them top end up the top end is the round end with the air pocket
They make egg steamer baskets that are useful when you need to make a ton of eggs

>>18904388
>Photograph better than the painting.
The painting is 400 years old. Significant amounts of the original pigment has faded or discolored, so you are not seeing it as vibrant as it would have been originally.

That said, making photography look like painting is not at all trivial, just as making painting look like photography is not trivial (it's not simply about realism). Also the photograph adds in dynamic elements like the smoke plume and the frontal skull face that change the focus of the original significantly and should be judged on its own merits, so you're free to like it more or less on those terms. But generally you should separate that from your judgement of a medium and an era (which you can like or not like as a whole, but that's different from liking or not liking a specific artwork in said medium from another in a different medium).

>>18902536
>always
either you're doing it wrong or you keep buying eggs that come from the same source and this is just a byproduct of the egg's composition (genetic/diet) and processing.
from my observation, eggs that have this problem have a thick, dry membrane. possibly it's because this keeps water out during the cooking process, the white's surface will also be dry and they become stuck together. whereas you really want there to be a wet interface so that the membrane can slide off after cooking. i'm not sure, scientifically, what could actually affect that in the few minutes of boiling, but i'm sure that's the cause. the rest is decided before you cook so there's not much you can do about it. i've also found that brown eggs are more likely to have thick/tough membranes so i prefer white for boiling. (egg color is genetic also)

That's it. I'm sick of all this "Masterwork German Knight" bullshit that's going on in the cooking culture right now. Japanese knives deserve much better than that. Much, much better than that.

I should know what I'm talking about. I myself commissioned a genuine Japanese knife in Japan for 2,400,000 Yen (that's about $20,000) and have been practising with it for almost 2 years now. I can even cut slabs of solid prime cut with my knife.

Japanese smiths spend years working on a single knife and fold it up to a million times to produce the finest blades known to mankind.

Japanese knives are thrice as sharp as European swords and thrice as hard for that matter too. Anything a French knife can cut through, a Japanese knife can cut through better. I'm pretty sure a Japanese knife could easily bisect a cow wearing full plate with a simple vertical slash.

Ever wonder why medieval Europe never bothered conquering Japan? That's right, they were too scared to fight the disciplined sushi chefs and their Japanese knives of destruction. Even in World War II, American soldiers targeted the men with the Japanese knives first because their killing power was feared and respected.

So what am I saying? Japanese knives are simply the best chef tool that the world has ever seen, and thus, require better stats in the d20 system. Here is the stat block I propose for Japanese knives:

(One-Handed Exotic Weapon)
1d12 Damage
19-20 x4 Crit
+2 to hit and damage
Counts as Masterwork

(Two-Handed Exotic Weapon)
2d10 Damage
17-20 x4 Crit
+5 to hit and damage
Counts as Masterwork

Now that seems a lot more representative of the cutting power of Japanese knives in real life, don't you think?

tl;dr = Japanese knives need to do more damage in cooking culture, see my new stat block.

>>18908296
You should season your ingredients and adjust the flavor as early as possible. If you're adding salt late enough that it doesn't have time to dissolve, then you're doing it wrong. Also, if your salt has big chunks, then it's the wrong kind. You want something light and flakey. They dissolve quickly, and will more evenly stick to foods.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18908296
The point of kosher salt is to have a larger grain which gives you more control when pinching with your fingers. If you know the required quantity beforehand (from a recipe) or are confident with finer grains you can use table salt with wet ingredients and sauces and get the exact same results. And of course for baking you should always use a fine-grained salt like table salt.

You have pictured a four cheese Mexican blend!
To reproduce this product using block cheese is not an insignificant task. Your supply chain needs to source each of these four cheeses, and inventory them all simultaneously. Cross-contamination is out of the question, so you will need to have four separate and sterilized grating tools, or, you could grate the first cheese, then wash the grater, and reuse it for the subsequent cheese, with a washing step in between each. Its not that hard, but you asked me, "what is the point?"
The point is you can avoid all of those steps, and still have Mexican blend cheese, without any hassle!
But, you also claim it wont taste as good as the freshly grated method, so we will assume the manually grated option is much better for you! Because you deserve the very best.

>>18903193
You have milk and sugar. You can make caramel treats.
You can also spike your baked beans with some smokey caramelized sugar (not the same as making milk caramels) if you cook it just right in the pan. This will make them taste warmer and add some calories for what sounds like a survival situation.
Olive oil can be turned into mayonnaise in a pinch by getting an acid and whipping it together until emulsified. If your beans have a tomato based sauce, there's your acid. Mayo is high satiety due to the fat in it, but I won't lie: tomato-olive mayo will be vile unless you have other ingredients you haven't listed like spices. You can then strain a can of beans, mash them into a paste, bruah with soy sauce, and cook that patty in the oven until dry. Apply mayo to the cooked patty.
Caramel energy drink: get your milk really cold, but not frozen. Make the caramel treats above but leave them a liquid. Mix sugar with the cold milk and caramel sauce for a flat shake.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18908255
What I've found is to specifically source out the "thick cut" pork chops for more reliable cooking. Most of the supermarket thin cut chops end up like you said, easily overcooked and leathery due to how lean they're cut with virtually no fat in the muscle. They're so easy to overcook you have to baby them and watch them like a hawk or they overcook instantly.

I pretty much treat them as burgers, 2-3 minutes on each side on medium-high heat if they're fully defrosted at room temperature.

For the thick cut ones, I generally go 4-6 minutes depending on how thick, but it varies from cut to cut. I'll typically keep a probe thermometer handy and measure every 2 minutes or so to make sure I've got the right temperature lined up.

IIRC, if you add salt to processed meat (ground, schnitzel-pounded), it causes the meat to 'sweat' excessively during cooking (so it dries too much/quickly). Said structure is destroyed when mechanically processing the piece.

The one i make myself, just a simple vinegar based sauce.

50g Scotch bonnets, 120g generic red chillies for flavour not heat, half a small onion, 3 cloves of garlic, 240ml apple cider vinegar, 5g salt. Chop all of it and add everything to a sauce pan, simmer for 10 minutes, let cool slightly then add to a blender untill smooth.

posts.com: if i cook thin chicken breast strips wrapped in bacon, is it safe to assume the bacon has finished cooking when the check breast reaches 180 internal temperature? i know its apparently rare in the US outside self butchered meat it but still drives my anxiety through the roof

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: slightly cook the bacon before wrapping

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Depending on the processing of the bacon you can eat it raw without health consequences. Properly cured and smoked pork has already been cooked to an appropriate temperature. If you are really worried you can sous vide it to 72C to cook it again and it will remain pliable. In a commercial kitchen I worked in we would wrap the bacon around the raw chicken and cover in cling wrap. Then we would poach it. Allow it to cool and heavy sear the outside to get the correct texture for the bacon. A lot of grocery store bacon here in Australia has not been smoked or cured correctly using faster chemical agents for flavoring so cooking to 75C is recommended but it isn't necessary and really isn't ideal unless you like your food dry.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18908476
Bacon is cured, so it will remain pink after cooking. Yes if the chicken is cooked the bacon will be cooked.

The only way you could fuck this up would be if you cooked the whole thing from the top only, then the bottom might be raw both in the bacon and the chicken department.

Frankly because bacon is salted and cured you'd have a really hard time poisoning yourself with it

>>18906712
Well, vodka can be made from corn too but moonshine is still not vodka. The difference might surprise you. Vodka is a higher proof distillate than moonshine. In production it's made into a neutral spirit which is nearly pure ethanol, then it's proofed down with water. Moonshine doesn't have to be proofed down, hence its high proof from the bottle. It is, however, less thoroughly distilled in production compared to vodka, leaving you with less ethanol by volume due to other things being left in.

>>18906529
The original Mountain Dew wasn't the Mountain Dew of today. The post-prohibition whiskey mixer the Hartmans created was originally a generic lemon-lime soda like 7-Up that sold like shit. After more than a decade of mediocrity, eventually they started bottling a revised version of the citrus formula in 1960 that basically ripped off Sun Drop and used orange juice to give it that same kind of taste, and they called it Tri-City Lemonade. They began bottling Tri-City Lemonade in the Mountain Dew bottles with the hillbilly on it, and eventually it became a hit and Pepsi bought the brand and formula. They don't sell the original formula anymore, but the old Tri-Cities bottler that used to make Mountain Dew still sells the old citrus soda that overshadowed it at the time -- Dr. Enuf. It has a unique taste and was originally sold as a hangover cure alongside the old Mountain Dew mixers.

Porridge and molasses were cheaper than alternatives in the 30s, but nowadays it's gotta be rice (whole grain if possible) and beans. Barley is cheap as well, in the bean section, and has lots of protein. All of which can be cooked in the microwave. Chicken is super efficient and heavily subsidized if you need meat. Canned anchovies if you need extra omega 3s. Spices: salt and whole pepper with reusable grinder from thrift store, plus oregano, cinnamon, and bay leaves, getting Badia or other cheap brands. Really you can get all the nutrition you ever need for super duper cheap nowadays. And there are plenty of free meals programs, and of course food stamps. There's no excuse for starving or not eating well like in the depression.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18877773
I came up with the idea for Peat Monster, nice to see it mentioned here. The first batch was a 50/50 blend of Caol Ila and Clynelish (or maybe Ardmore, it was a long time ago lol), both about 10 or 15 years old, aged in ex-bourbon, and bottled at cask strength. It was just called Monster. John Glaser, the founder, didn’t want to make it at first because he didn’t personally enjoy peaty whisky. It turned out to be the blend that put him on the map, so he decided to make it regular production item as Peat Monster, with some water added to lower the proof.

>>18899502
you've gone about it wrong from the start if you thought cheap flavored whiskey would be easier to drink or be free of the quality's of ethanol and how it affects your body.

first learn how to drink(approach it like a hot beverage or soup, less is more, savor it for as long as you can muster and do not do shots). then find what you like to drink(better to have 2 or more bottles poured at once to compare and find your sweetspot). then you combine those aspects and become all that is man(who can appreciate the glass in his hand as well as the drink within).

if you're only looking for inebriation then go down the buttchug path.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18905344
something from Caol Ila, but not bottled by Diageo. so basically any Islay single malt that is branded but never names the distillery is 9/10 times Caol Ila and usually about 1/2 the price of the officially bottled 12 and with better representation of the malt.

in terms of overall taste, Kilchoman Machir Bay is very similar to Ardbeg 10 in my experience, but I enjoy Kilchoman more. it sounds cheesey but you can taste the integrity of the farm-to-bottle aspect in Kilchoman. richer and oilier than Ardbeg without the industrial edge. Machir Bay is usually 5-7 years old with a small amount of sherry maturation, but it tastes like 10 year old whisky where as Ardbeg 10 tastes like younger whisky from less active casks.

If you find a bottle of The 6 Isles, that will be a good adjacent pour. if not that then Ledaig 10. recent batches have been more/less sherried so pay attention to the color if you arent crazy about that combination.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18905434
I was a buyer for major retailers and also worked the spirits auction market. I have tasted whisky from pretty much every distillery that has operated in the last century, at many different ages. I've had several 50+ year old Macallans and Glenlivets, many 30+ year old Springbanks, Ardbegs, and Port Ellens, etc. People respect my tastes.

Johnny Walker Blue is a magnificent blend. The fact that it contains grain whisky does nothing to detract from its quality. Try an old single grain bottling if you have the chance, they can be wonderful whiskies. Not sure if he still makes it, but Compass Box Hedonism is a good intro to quality aged grain whisky.

Is Blue Label overpriced? It definitely used to be when you could buy Macallan 18 and Springbank 21 for under $100. But now that older malts are so outrageously expensive, I'd say Blue Label is actually a good deal considering the age and quality of the malts in it.

>>18893872

Yucatecan is my favorite Mexican regional cuisine. It's alot of citrus, habanero, interesting colors, balancing between bright citrus and spicy with earthy annatto and deep black charred produce, seafood, and the infamous cocinita pibil. Some yucatecan deep cuts are sikil pak (it's like a roasted habanero pumpkin seed salsa with the consistency of hummus), xni pec (pink fruity habanero salsa), Recado negro (black habanero salsa made out of burned chiles and tortillas), panuchos/salbutes (puffy tostada/tacos stuffed with beans), and huaraches (Mexican flat breads)

>>18897509
>spaniards introduce spirits in America. Are even less know fact is that the exact process of distilling tequila/mezcal came from filipinos.
>https://www.sapiens.org/culture/tequila-origins-tuba/
None of that is what is said in your source link. Here is the exact paragraph quote:
>They brought coconuts, along with techniques to ferment coconut sap into tuba—an alcoholic beverage consumed in the Philippines since precolonial times, and sometimes distilled into a stronger coconut liquor known as lambanog or bahalina. These fermentation and distillation techniques were applied to agave—a plant native to Mexico and other parts of the Americas—eventually becoming what we now know as tequila (from blue agave) and mezcal (from other agave varieties).
Thus this particular researcher is saying that the distillation process was introduced based on a precolonial process in the Philippines. So "Spaniards introduce spirits in America" is blatantly false in every way (for every definition of "spirits").

In terms of history, tequila by any measure is one of the oldest distilled spirits consumed in mass today, with genever being older. Alcohol is ancient, but consistently drinkable distilled spirits are relatively much more recent.

>>18904711
They make for a great picnic in June, preferably on the beach, with freshly pickled young herring ("maatjes"), jenever (Belgian/Dutch/French/German version of gin) and floury potato (pref polder Bintje)/shallot/mustard (pref strong Tierenteyn from Ghent)/flatleaf parsley salad.

You can replace the maatjes with any fat cured/smoked fish. Mackerel, salmon, trout, eel.

You can replace the jenever with gin, Grappa, vodka. Anything along those lines. Choose something with quality. You can't really replace the flatleaf parsley or polder Bintjes.

Not that anon

Pickled eggs:
6 eggs, 250 ml alcohol vinegar, 250 ml cider vinegar, 1 tbsp sugar, ½ tbsp salt, 1 tsp dill seeds, 1 raw beetroot sliced, 1 red onion sliced

Boil eggs for 9 minutes, peel, put in a weck pot. Bring vinegars, sugar and salt to a boil. Add remaining ingredients to the weck pot, pour until covered with vinegar, lock while still warm. Store for 2 days up to 6 weeks.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18905181
Did you boil your brine/vinegar before pouring it in your mason jar? I find that doing that and routinely flipping the jar while it is cooling helps reduce potential mold growth.
Post pictures of the fuzzy. Although it's very NOT recommended, I've salvaged a moldy jar before. When I first noticed a bit of white fuzz inside the jar near the lid I trashed anything above the brine surface and dumped the submerged eggs in a bowl, and rinsed them in hot tap water multiple times to remove any residue from the jar. Ate them promptly for lunch and I was fine. Most mold doesn't like vinegar due to the acidity, so the likelihood of it reaching below into the brine and tainting eggs if you catch it quickly is low.
Of course, that is a risk I was willing to take and is not recommended.

posts.com: Why do people say this place is good, and talk about it like it's an elevated experience compared to the other big burger chains? Why do they even like it? Wendy's is the nastiest fast food I've ever had, and I've tried almost everything on the menu. All their food lacks salt and is completely flavorless and bland, and usually it has a faint taste of bleach or some sort of cleaner. Even the burgers that look like they're supposed to have flavor like the baconator or the limited time specialty ones are all completely bland. >>18901303
It's a really good question and the answer is disappointing: your taste buds work differently in different situations. Stress, holidays, altitude, having to pay, eating together with your partner, memories from childhood, food & drink pairings etc etc all drastically change the way you perceive taste/aroma.

I once got a sangria recipe from a colleague in Barcelona which was phenomenal. We had 50-70m queues all day. When I got back home and tried it in my restaurant it was ok at best. The opposite can (rarely) happen too: you can buy crates of mediocre wine when you taste them which turn out to be gems when you get home.

Instead of learning synonyms for fucking I'd advise you to read Marcel Proust instead.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Been working at a place off and on for the last 4 years(covid and having a serious medical issue made it so it was more like 2 ACTUAL years of regular shifts).
Notice my raises were all but erased because of a minimum wage going up(Started off with the manager saying all line cooks start at $2 over minimum wage, and get raises every 9-12 months based on performance. Because of covid i never got the last 2 evaluations). Since then minimum wage has gone up by $1.85 cents.
New hires are actually paid more than me, even though i literally had to show one how to use a fucking thermometer last time i worked with him.
Tip-outs was also really exaggerated, with the manager saying it averages around $2/hr for BoH. At best, i did maybe $2.20/hr, but prob 80% of the time its around $1/hr.

Pretty fucking demoralized desu. I'm thinking of just handing in my notice tomorrow. I'm also given shitty shifts(like both opening shifts on the weekend. Something that i guess only a few other guys are trained to do.) that are impossible to offload and would cripple the business if i did a no-show.
I'll admit i'm probably one of the weaker cooks there if you only look at the people who are actually fully trained, but i'v never missed a day or came in late, never take breaks(so many other guys just fuck-off for smoke breaks or disappear in the bathroom for 20 minutes. I made it a point to not use the bathroom unless i literally need to) and have stayed past the end of my shift if asked.
I know its a shitty industry to work in, and i have said so myself plenty of times, but when i actually took a moment to reflect on it when i got my tax papers for it, it really hit me just how exploited i feel from working there.

At my place, we'd make i think 18L every 3 or 4 days, and keep it in a big cambro in the cooler. At the start of the day we'd heat up enough to fill a 1/3rd tray and keep it in a steamwell, and add to it if needed.

I also worked at a place that would portion it out in 10oz bags, and re-heat(in the microwave) to order. Steam well works better since its uniformly warm and for some stuff you need to put it in a pipping bag anyway, so having it portioned in a plastic bag is just wasteful and extra hassle.

Never worked as a line cook, but I did briefly work at a factory that made frozen tv dinners and hot meals for Meals on Wheels, and cafeterias too. I never looked at a tv dinner the same way after that job.

While I personally prefer cow milk over goat (goat one has a weird taste that doesn't quite sit with me), goat cheese is kino

Supposedly goat milk/cheese is easier to digest if you have any problems with that (small lipid globules). Goat dairy products have more vitA, calcium, potassium, phosphorus and niacin, so technically healthier. It is more caloric, has more protein (on average) but more sodium.

Like I said, I don't recommend goat milk unless you can put up with the taste of grass (at least that's how I'd describe it), but cheese is really good and goes fantastic with a fresh slice of bread and a slice of smoked ham.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18904389
Don't have a picture because it's pretty mundane, but I've made it many times. Grate some cheese fresh - I generally use basic cheddar like Cabot extra sharp, but you can use whatever you want (a lot of people do half cheddar and half American). Don't buy pre-grated cheese, ever. Add it to a bowl with some mayonnaise. Ratio depends on how much cheese you use. Add your pimentos, and some Worcestershire and cayenne. Mash it all together into a spread. Can make it more homogenous in your stand mixer with the paddle attachment.

The seasonings are a matter of taste, so put whatever you like. Try some granulated onion or garlic, hot sauce, whatever. Pimento cheese is one of those things that is infinitely better if you make it at home. It's cheap, easy, and none of the store bought will match it. Another note is to use good mayonnaise. I always use Duke's. Never, ever use Miracle Whip (just save yourself some time and never, ever buy Miracle Whip).

>>18893364
KFC and McDonalds both did and excellent job with localization to new markets. Subway has had consistently cheap options.

But USA in general went from an obsession with fast food in fashion to a wide rejection of it with healthy eating snobbery, and then chains like those became associated with lower classes who often go to fast food for convenience (less free time for cooking or less education in cooking due to less attentive parents or parents who never cooked at home for similar reasons). In many other countries (like many parts of Asia), cooking at home became and old-school traditionalist way of doing things that became associated with the poor, and urban fast food became the hip stylish thing.

From what I recall in many parts of Europe, this didn't happen because there was a longstanding tradition of restaurants in general being associated with low quality food, and cooking at home being associated with good family and leisure. Now due to cross-culture influence and tourism restaurants have gotten better, and increasing urbanization means less kitchen space for young people, and smaller families means less incentive to cook, so there is likely more fast food in vogue in Europe now, but that's balanced against them adopting (or starting) many of the upper-class fashions (like health food) of North America

A standard box grater has a slicer side on it if you need perfect evenness. You can look up how to hone and sharpen it if necessary. Or use the rough grater. (Also a food processor will obviously come with a grater/slicer attachment.)
